theText: The Ministersame time, we knew of the Indian Government's difficulties in making adequate supplies of cotton goods available to normal export markets. At the close of last year it became apparent that the supply of textiles in Australia was overtaking uie demand. Accordingly, the Indian authorities were informed that Australia was able to relinquish most of the quota of cotton piece-goods that had heen provided by India to meet our earlier anticipated governmental requirements. In addition the trade was approached by my department with the object of determining to what extent we could relieve the Indian Government from their obligation to release for export our quota for civilian use. The position now is that, because Australian importers did not place orders in India for cotton piece-goods and cotton yarn to the extent anticipated when tlie. trade arrangement was negotiated, the Indian Government, after consultation with the Australian Government, has removed the former provision for a stipulated quota of cotton piece-goods and cotton yarn for Australia. Australian importers may still participate in the overall export quotas announced by thc Indian Government, but their ability to make purchase is affected hy the import licensing measures introduced in Australia on the Sth March. 2. Australian cotton spinning and weaving mills intimated that they were holding substantial stocks and, in the absence of sales, were forced to .'curtail production. The deterioration in the cotton textiles trade is not confined to Australia but is world-wide, and the rapid decline in the trade during the first quarter'of this calendar year has led to thc increasing curtailment of production in many countries. The situation is manifest in the United Kingdom, Continental Europe, the United States of America, and even in Japan where the Japanese Government has advised cotton spinners to reduce production to 60 per. cent, of capacity over the next quarter. During the debate on the adjournment moved by the honourable member for Burke on Thursday, the 28th February, Ministers acknowledged thc concern of the Government at the position which hod overtaken the Australian cotton spinning and weaving industries. It was then explained that this was the result of developments abroad leading to the unexpected fulfilment of outstanding orders plared overseas by importers at a time when Australian manufacturers were unable to cope with the demand. The House was also told of the Government's measures to relieve the position, including the placing of defence orders in Australia to help tide over the period of adjustment'. The import licensing measures which were brought in recently for currency and balance of payment -reasons have, incidentally, increased the protection against overseas competition In theadministration of these measures, moreover, the Government will aim to ensure that essential supplies of imported raw materials are available to the cotton spinning and weaving industries. 3.
